[start of motion plan]
The task is to break the wrist while grasping the wrist.

Understanding Robot-Applied Forces and Torques to Move Object in the Wrist Frame:
To estimate the forces and torques required to accomplish break the wrist while grasping the wrist, we must consider the following:
- Object Properties: The robot wrist appears to be a mechanical joint connecting the robotic arm to the end-effector (gripper). It likely consists of metal components, possibly aluminum or steel, with internal bearings, cables, and electronic components. The wrist joint is designed to allow controlled motion but has structural limits beyond which damage occurs.
- Environmental Factors: Gravity will be acting downward on the wrist mechanism. The robot arm appears to be positioned above a wooden workspace table. The wrist joint likely has internal resistance designed to prevent unintended motion, and may have mechanical stops to limit range of motion.
- The relevant object is the robot's own wrist joint, which is a mechanical component connecting the arm to the end-effector has mass 0.5 kg and, with the robot gripper, has a static friction coefficient of 0.3.
- The surface of interaction is internal to the wrist joint mechanism with metal-on-metal contacts that has a static friction coefficient of 0.2 with the object.
- Contact Types: The task involves maintaining a firm grasp on the wrist while applying excessive force or torque beyond the wrist's design specifications.
- Motion Type: The motion involves applying extreme rotational force around one or more axes of the wrist joint until mechanical failure occurs. This likely requires exceeding the torque limits of the internal components.
- Contact Considerations: The robot needs to maintain a secure grip on the wrist while applying extreme torque. The grip must be firm enough to prevent slipping during the application of breaking force.
- Motion along axes: The robot exerts motion in a rotational fashion primarily along the wrist's rx and ry axes, with some linear force along the z-axis to maintain stability during the breaking motion.
- Task duration: Based on the mechanical resistance of typical robot wrist joints and the force application needed, the task would take approximately 3 seconds to complete.

Physical Model (if applicable):
- Relevant quantities and estimates: Typical robot wrist breaking torque threshold: 15-20 N-m; Wrist joint mass: approximately 0.5 kg; Required grip force: 50-70 N.
- Relevant equations: Torque = Force × Distance from pivot point; Breaking occurs when applied torque > maximum torque rating of the wrist.
- Relevant assumptions: The wrist has a maximum torque rating of approximately 18 N-m; The breaking point is most vulnerable around the Y rotation axis; The wrist has some built-in resistance to prevent damage.
- Computations: To break the wrist, we need to exceed its maximum torque rating. Assuming a lever arm of approximately 0.1 m from the rotation axis to the application point, and a maximum torque rating of 18 N-m, we need to apply a force of at least 180 N perpendicular to this lever arm.
- Force/torque motion computations with object of mass 0.5 kg and static friction coefficient of 0.2 along the surface: The primary breaking mechanism will be rotational torque rather than linear force. The wrist's mass contributes minimally to the required breaking force since we're exceeding structural limits rather than overcoming inertia.

Wrist Force/Torque Motion Estimation:
Linear X-axis: To complete the task and based upon stabilizing the wrist during the breaking motion, the robot must exert positive force along the X-axis with magnitude 30 N on the object in the image.
Linear Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon providing counter-force to the rotational motion, the robot must exert negative force along the Y-axis with magnitude 25 N on the object in the image.
Linear Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon maintaining downward pressure to secure the wrist during breaking, the robot must exert negative force along the Z-axis with magnitude 40 N on the object in the image.
Angular X-axis: To complete the task and based upon exceeding the mechanical limits of the wrist joint structure, the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the X-axis with magnitude 20 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Y-axis: To complete the task and based upon applying the primary breaking force to the most vulnerable axis of the wrist, the robot must exert angular clockwise torque about the Y-axis with magnitude 25 N-m on the object in the image.
Angular Z-axis: To complete the task and based upon adding torsional stress to complement the primary breaking forces, the robot must exert angular counterclockwise torque about the Z-axis with magnitude 15 N-m on the object in the image.
Grasping force: Based on the need to maintain a secure grip during high-torque application without slipping, and considering the wrist's surface material and the forces involved, 60 to 80 N.

Python Code with Final Motion Plan:
```python
# succinct text description of the explicit estimated physical properties of the object, including mass, material, friction coefficients, etc.
property_description = "Robot wrist joint: metal construction, 0.5 kg mass, 0.2 friction coefficient, maximum torque rating of approximately 18 N-m"
# succinct text description of the motion plan along the wrist axes
wrist_motion_description = "Apply extreme rotational torque primarily around X and Y axes while maintaining downward pressure and secure grip until mechanical failure occurs"
# the vector (sign of direction * magnitude) of the forces and torques along the wrist's [x, y, z, rx, ry, rz] axes
wrist_wrench = [30, -25, -40, 20, -25, 15]
# the grasping force, which must be positive
grasp_force = 70
# the task duration, which must be positive
duration = 3.0
```

[end of motion plan]

The robot is controlled using position and torque-based control, with access to contact feedback and 6D motion capabilities.

Motion can resolve across multiple axes, so be careful to consider all axes of motion to accomplish the task.

Reason about the provided and implicit information in the images and task description to generate a structured plan for the robot's motion. Think about:
- Object geometry and contact points (from the image)
- Force/torque sensing at the wrist
- Prior knowledge of object material types and mass estimates
- Environmental knowledge (table, gravity, hinge resistance, etc.)

The robot workspace view labeled with the axes of motion relative to the wrist of the robot, placed at the point of grasping. The wrist of the robot may be oriented differently from the canonical world-axes, so this workspace view may help understand the wrist-relative motion to accomplish the task in the world.
World Motion Reference: As ground truth reference for world motion relative to the robot, the workspace camera view roughly corresponds to canonical motion in the world. 
Upward motion in the world corresponds to motion up workspace camera view image, 
Right-ward motion in the world corresponds to motion to the right of the workspace camera view image, 
And forward motion in the world corresponds to motion into the workspace camera view image.
The wrist frame axes will roughly correspond to these directions, but will be more aligned with the gripper-object relative motion.

Rules:
1. Replace all {DESCRIPTION: ...}, {PNUM}, {NUM}, and {CHOICE: ...} entries with specific values or statements. For example, {PNUM} should be replaced with a number like 0.5. This is very important for downstream parsing!!
2. Use best physical reasoning based on known robot/environmental capabilities. Remember that the robot may have to exert forces in additional axes compared to the motion direction axes in order to maintain contacts between the object, robot, and environment.
3. Always include motion for all axes of motion, even if it's "No motion required."
4. Keep the explanation concise but physically grounded. Prioritize interpretability and reproducibility.
5. Use common sense where exact properties are ambiguous, and explain assumptions.
6. Do not include any sections outside the start/end blocks or add non-specified bullet points.
7. Make sure to provide the final python code for each requested force in a code block. Remember to fully replace the placeholder text with the actual values!
8. Do not abbreviate the prompt when generating the response. Fully reproduce the template, but filled in with your reasoning.
9. Make sure to refer to the provided correspondence in the direction guide between motion in the world frame and positive/negative motion in the respective axes.
